Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase II: Termite-derived enzymatic tree bio-herbicides
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact and commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer and Research (STTR) project is a method to control invasive or otherwise unwanted trees and shrubs in an ecologically friendly manner with a biodegradable product. This will reduce the quantity of synthetic herbicides and/or synthetic herbicide adjuvants currently applied to control woody plants. This is especially needed near waterways where vegetation managers must choose between expensive mechanical removal or potential harm to sensitive ecosystems. Homeowners, landscapers, farmers, conservationists, utilities, and other customers will have a new product to control invasive trees and shrubs consistent with a mission to be good stewards of the environment.

This STTR Phase II project proposes to follow initial successful Phase I demonstrations of an enzymatic bio-herbicide or herbicide adjuvant following the principles of termite biomimicry. The objectives of this Phase II project are to identify the mode-of-action, develop high- and medium-throughput bioassays in vitro and in planta, optimize the product formulation, and demonstrate efficacy on various invasive species in the field such as bush honeysuckle (Lonicera maackii), tree of heaven (Ailanthus altissima), glossy buckthorn (Frangula alnus), bamboo (Phyllostachys aurea), and potentially others.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to develop a natural herbicide for trees and shrubs. This herbicide was to contain enzymes derived from termites, fungal enzymes called cellulases used in the pulp and paper industry that digest cellulose (a major component of wood), and natural phytotoxins. The bark of mature trees and shrubs protects them from herbicides. Killing a tree or shrub with herbicide most often requires wounding the bark to allow the herbicide to penetrate either by cutting a trunk then applying herbicide to the stump (“stump paint”) or by cutting a wound with a hatchet and spraying herbicide into the wound “hack-and-squirt”). However, trees and shrubs start sealing their wounds immediately after injury in order to prevent water loss and infection. To be effective, herbicide must be applied shortly after wounding.

Natural phytotoxins are typically much weaker and more expensive than synthetic herbicides. To improve their efficacy, our hypothesis was to combine phytotoxins with fungal and termite-derived enzymes that would prevent the wounds from sealing and thus allowing more time for the trees to absorb the phytotoxin.

We tested this on poplar trees grown in greenhouse, poplar trees grown in a field, and glossy buckthorn present in a natural setting. Our results in greenhouse demonstrate that cellulases can greatly improve herbicide efficacy. However, the effect was not as clear when applied to poplars or buckthorn in the field. It is possible that the harsher environment of the field could reduce the efficacy of the enzyme or require a different combination than we were able to investigate by the end of this project.
